content:
We handle text-decoration on links somewhat inconsistently:

  • Markdown headings (self-link): underline on hover
  • Rustdoc headings (self-link): none
  • Markdown hyperlinks: underline on hover
  • Top of page h1 (self-link and breadcrumbs): underline on hover
  • Jump to definition: underline on hover
  • Sidebar: highlight on hover
  • Links to items in a module (e.g.): none
  • Links to types (e.g. in method signature): none

Any thoughts on making these more consistent? I'm leaning towards consolidating on "underline on hover." That would mean changes to Rustdoc headings, sidebar, links to items in a module, and links to types.
Having underline on hover seems like the best thing to do. I really like how we do it for the paths
The underline on hover actually bothers me. I feel like it'd make the method signature look worse.

underline on hover doesn't bother me in general; I do have a vague feeling it would be distracting in method signatures. One possibility would be to add underline on hover to Rustdoc headings (a clear oversight when compared to Markdown headings) and links to items in a module, but continue to have "none" for method signatures.
Maybe the best way to test this is to just have a demo. One sec.

Also, I think you didn't mention the type declaration at the top of the page. That's inconsistent with method headings in that it has underline on hover. That's really the only inconsistency that's bothered me before.
Ah you mean the top-doc docblock?
No, the type-decl (I think that's the class).
yeah, we're talking about the same thing - I was using the wrong class
The stuff that Manish Goregaokar made shown by default.
(Which I think was a great change; I just don't like the underline on hover.)
E.g. the grey box at the top of https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/error/trait.Error.html and the links inside it.
Yep
There's another minor inconsistency there. Some things are hyperlinked, but others aren't (like the variants in Result - https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/result/enum.Result.html)
I think because those are the definition, not references.

alright, here's a demo where all hyperlinks get underline on hover: https://rustdoc.crud.net/jsha/underlines/std/string/struct.String.html#method.as_mut_vec

a:hover {
    text-decoration: underline !important;
}

We could also go the opposite direction and say nothing gets underlines on hover.

Or a third way: things get underlines on hover if there's nothing else that particularly marks them out as links.

Or a fourth way: underline on hover indicates some property of the link (for instance that it's a self-link).
Yeah, I don't think it's horrible, but overall I think I like the old version better.
Except for the type decl, the current rule is that only Markdown links (including Markdown headings) get underlines.
I think type decls shouldn't get underlines, and I could imagine Markdown headings not getting underlines, leaving only user-written Markdown links as getting underlines.
Here's a useful page about non-color indicators for links, with the lens of accessibility: https://usability.yale.edu/web-accessibility/articles/links#designing-links

Lately I've been using MDN as a guidepost on styling questions. I think they have really good design. I believe put a lot of effort into accessibility, and a lot of people like their site a lot.

Here's an example page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Containment

Their approach seems very similar to what the Yale article says. For items where the linkiness is obvious from position (sidebar, breadcrumbs, headings), there's no default text-decoration, but they get underline on hover.

For links embedded in text, e.g. contain in the first paragraph article, there is an unconditional underline.

There's no equivalent in MDN of our "heading with multiple links in it," so no good comparison there.
